metadata.subject: Your Tuesday News Briefing: Rod Rosenstein, the U.N., Hong Kong

relationships.description: Deputy Attorney General overseeing Russia investigation, subject of President Trump's anger
China asserting control over Hong Kong's political activities and religious practices
U.S. as largest financial contributor to UN while pursuing isolationist policies

transactions: Michael Kors potential acquisition of Versace

analysis.purpose: To provide a morning news briefing covering major world events
analysis.significance: Comprehensive coverage of significant political, international, and business developments on September 24, 2018

notable_quotes: Mr. Kavanaugh on Monday called the allegations 'smears' and said he 'will not be intimidated into withdrawing.'
The U.S. remains the biggest single financial contributor to the U.N. But the Trump administration has pursued increasingly isolationist, America First policies
Faulkner rarely discussed his love of mysteries, perhaps considering them lowbrow, but seemed to understand their importance to his writing

blackmail_indicators.description: No indicators of blackmail or coercion found in this news briefing document

illegal_activity.description: This is a news article reporting on various events; no first-hand illegal activity by the sender or participants

details: Multiple references to New York Times articles and other media outlets
Contact information for briefing feedback provided

public_knowledge.context: This is a published news briefing from The New York Times covering significant international news events from September 2018

analysis.summary: This New York Times morning briefing covers major international news including Rod Rosenstein's meeting with President Trump, Hong Kong's crackdown on independence movements, the UN General Assembly meeting, China's increased control over Christianity, and various business and cultural developments from September 24, 2018.
